Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2012 04:56AM hendricks1 wrote: Thanks CoolBreeze-you are obviously in a good place with this.  Hoping I eventually will be.  They said I have some ascites on my liver which has me concerned.  I suppose if tx is doing its job it will go away so I just need to be patient.  I felt a small lump in my stomach back in July and by the beginning of September it was really large so I know that this is aggressive.  So hard to remain calm! LuAnnH-I may have had my head in the sand but I've never kept track of TMs myself-guess I need to ask my Dr.  I just had a check up in June which detected nothing in my blood work or liver enzymes-crazy! Thanks for the comments!
Posts.Title: Herceptin & Tykerb-How quickly do you know its working? hendricks1 sueopp

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2012 06:16AM hendricks1 wrote: LuvRVing-I'll be thinking of you this next week and hoping for great news from your scans.  I go for my 2nd herceptin treatment on Wednesday. Sueopp-I hate that you've had to bounce around so much but we just do whatever we have to right? And there's still Perjeta? Wondering if you have ever looked into Hyperthermia?  Not common in the US but other countries-I've had some people give me good feedback about it.  Guess I'm keeping that in the back of my mind if things aren't working-though some might say it's best not to wait til then. I'll be hoping that we all stay stable-I have faith there will be a cure! Take care ladies!

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 04:48AM hendricks1 wrote: Just had to share my good news-had appt yesterday with my onc who said that my tumor markers had gone down from 140 to 110 in the last week!  Also, my elevated liver enzymes are back to close to normal.  I've only had two treatments but it seems like the herceptin/tykerb is working!  Amazing how a little good news can change your day : )

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2013 08:49PM hendricks1 wrote: Landaffqueen- are you just taking Xeloda?  I'm on Herceptin/Xeloda/BKM120 since June.  My liver mets were shrinking a good bit already on herceptin/perjeta/abraxane but in May found I had brain mets and they switched me to this trial.  Had been good til some feet neuropathy and a new Rx for that-since then I've had a crazy rash issue but I'm still here so gotta juggle the good and bad some I guess.  Hope you're doing well!  By the way I'm Her2+/ER-PR-

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2013 04:17PM hendricks1 wrote: Just got home from 3 nights in the hospital with Xeloda/BKM120 rash.  I think it's the sun sensitivity that really set it off but I've had an awful rash down my arms and around my torso-it follows the lines of my bra and pants so its like the rash flares up wherever the sun shines through my clothes.  Anyway, feel like a beached whale pumped with saline and steroids for 3 days.  Just thought I'd share my experience.  Don't know now if I'll be taken off the trial and what my next step will be but the Xeloda, while seeming to work on my brain mets, caused me feet and skin problems that were too severe. Anyway, on we go to the next thing right? Take care all!
Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: May 23, 2013 04:44AM hendricks1 wrote: Add me in there!  I too feel a bit guilty as I seem to visit when things are going rough.  Diagnosed with mets to liver in August 2012, got better with Abraxane/Perjeta/Herceptin only to get news yesterday that though my other issues are doing well, it's travelled to my brain.  Didn't know that those drugs don't help you there-they don't cross the blood/brain barrier.  I'll be starting a trial, radiation as last resort.  Cancer sucks!!
Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 10:24AM hendricks1 wrote: Hey Carabear-  Good luck with your surgery! You must be overwhelmed after being diagnosed so recently.   I had a few rounds of chemo (Adriamycin, Cytoxin) before having surgery (I did a lumpectomy in November) and I guess there are arguments for both sides of that, but the good thing for you is that you are positive for both hormones as well as HER2.  That means you have the most treatment options.  Chemo has been pretty easy for me, except for being allergic to Taxol.  Everyone responds differently but I hope it'll be easy for you like it was for me.  Prepare for losing your hair if you take Adriamycin-if your insurance covers it, get a human hair wig.  They are the best and can be colored/cut to look just like yours. Anyway, I thought I'd add one of the lists of good things to buy/tips to our thread.  There's more out there but these are some good things to think about. Justeasin11-sorry to hear about your situation.  This cancer crap never has good timing. Take care everyone!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2011 11:19AM hendricks1 wrote: Hi Ladies- I too, am 8 days out from surgery (BMX w/TEs).  Feeling better and just starting to feel like I can breathe normally.  Felt like someone has been standing on my chest for the last week. Can't lift much of anything-still feel a little weak but am getting more movement and range of motion in my arms.    My first observation scared me-my right breast is somewhat convex but my left was more concave.  I had a lumpectomy in November which left a 4 inch scar on my left side and apparently they had to take that skin out which left me with less to work with. Feel like I'm going to be 1 size off for a little while-probably just slower to expand.  No problems with swelling yet. I've been able to sleep fine in bed on my back-thank goodness for that! And my husband has been great about helping with my drains,bathing, etc.  Go back Tuesday for follow up...I'd say my only downfall in preparation was getting appropriate clothes for after getting home.  It's hot here in MS and though I love the Danskin zip up sweatshirts, they are too warm.  Anyone find anything like that in short sleeves? Good luck to those still waiting-you will sail through it!  Stay strong everyone : )
Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 10:13AM hendricks1 wrote: Hi Ladies- I too am an April lady-April 8 I will be doing double MX, with tissue expanders.  I have a 4 year old and 4 month old at home and opted for the quickest recovery so I can get back to my "mom duties"!  I too am nervous but ready to get on with it.  I already had a lumpectomy and just completed 3 months of Abraxane and Herceptin, then just have Herceptin every 3 weeks for the next 9 months.  After that, should be done!  What a long road it is. I've seen some lists on good tips to have/remember regarding surgery-do any of you have some things that you plan on doing/getting to make things easier??  I've ordered the Amoena camisole that has pockets for drains...any other ideas?   We will all get through this-glad to have others to chat with. Carabear-I think you're the only other HER2+ person on this thread-is your treatment similar as far as chemo? Take care-Gail
Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 05:51PM hendricks1 wrote: Hi Ladies- So glad to hear everyone's doing well.  Thanks for all the well wishes and I love hearing how everyone's coming along.   Had my post op appt earlier this week-drains out, no more meds, clear path report and feeling pretty good. Still feel like I"m slow in lifting things and need to get to where I can lift my 22 lb baby!  Also still adjusting to what's in the mirror-I have pretty long scars and even though TEs are in, I really look like a boy : )  NOt that I had lots before but it is just so different.  Oh well, I'm here, right??  That's what's important! Good luck to all of you still waiting to go and stay strong! Gail
Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 10:27AM hendricks1 wrote: I copied this from another thread-thought it might be helpful....    PLEASE add your suggestions!!! Anything at all you either found helpful OR wish you'd considered before your surgery. I am a bit of a MacGyver type and love creative uses for things like the lanyards and fanny packs for drains. I was wondering if a light/loose fly fishing vesy might be handy both for drains and for holding my phone, mp3 player, etc so I didn't have to reach so much... I am SUCH a geek. Anyway, over-organizing seems to be keeping me occupied as my bi-latteral approaches. I know everything won't be a hit with everyone, but it gives us some things to think about. Here we go, again, please add YOUR favorite tips-- Move commonly used items, kitchen tools, etc to low shelves before surgery Find NON child-proof caps for meds Have constipation meds ready Fill scripts before coming home so you won't have to stop on the way Have a pillow for the car-ride home. Have extras handy for propping up at home Lanyard (like for ID cards) for holding drains Fanny pack for drains Nurses can make a necklace from IV tubing to hold drains in shower Lip balm / lotion Mp3 / Music player Notebook for managing meds, etc Phone / have friends' numbers handy Take clothes to hospital that can be washed/sanitized at home slippers camisoles/tanks which can be stepped into (as opposed to pulling over-head) Silky bottoms/PJs to make getting in/out of bed easier button up shirts zip up hoodies/ warm ups pull on, easy pants Jog Bras (Natori is recommended) or whatever support is suggested by your surgeon
Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2011 11:14AM hendricks1 wrote: Hey Everyone- I'm getting ready for tomorrow, I guess AliT is with me.  Several have already gone-how are you all doing? Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2011 04:03PM hendricks1 wrote: Beaglesgirl- Just fyi-I was told I was triple negative in the beginning, then after my lumpectomy, they tested the tissue again to find that I was actually HER2+.  You never know, but yes, unfortunately, either way, we have fewer options.  I'm sorry for the chaos you are going through-it is all so overwhelming in the beginning.  You'll be fine though-we all will!  I know I don't have another option-I have a 4 year old and 5 month old to take care of : ) Good luck with everything-I think the tests are the worst part, I'd rather not ever have another PET scan, chemo isn't so bad!
